notes:
1. Concept

This is a very common type of combined loading, occurring in members like columns with eccentric loads or beams that are also under tension or compression. Both the axial load ($P$) and the bending moment ($M$) produce normal stresses that act in the same direction.

2. Principle of Superposition

The total normal stress at any point on the cross-section is the algebraic sum of the stress from the axial load and the stress from the bending moment.

$$ \sigma_{total} = \sigma_{axial} + \sigma_{bending} $$ $$ \sigma_{total} = \pm \frac{P}{A} \pm \frac{My}{I} $$
  • The axial stress ($P/A$) is constant across the entire cross-section. It is positive for tension and negative for compression.
  • The bending stress ($My/I$) varies linearly from the neutral axis. It will be tensile on one side of the axis and compressive on the other. The signs must be determined based on the direction of the moment.

3. Maximum and Minimum Stresses

The maximum and minimum normal stresses occur at the outermost fibers of the cross-section (where $y$ is maximum, denoted by $c$).

$$ \sigma_{max} = \frac{P}{A} + \frac{Mc}{I} $$$$ \sigma_{min} = \frac{P}{A} - \frac{Mc}{I} $$

solvedExamples.question: A rectangular column with a cross-section of 10 in x 10 in is subjected to a compressive axial load of 50,000 lbs and a bending moment of 100,000 in-lbs. What is the maximum compressive stress in the column?
solvedExamples.explanation: First, calculate the properties: Area $A = 10 \times 10 = 100$ in². Moment of Inertia $I = bh^3/12 = (10)(10)^3/12 = 833.3$ in⁴. Distance to outer fiber $c = 10/2 = 5$ in. Now calculate the stresses. Axial stress (compressive) = $-P/A = -50,000 / 100 = -500$ psi. Maximum bending stress = $\pm Mc/I = \pm (100,000)(5) / 833.3 = \pm 600$ psi. The maximum compressive stress occurs where the axial and bending compressive stresses add together: $\sigma_{max\ comp} = -500 - 600 = -1100$ psi. The magnitude is 1100 psi.
